Award.AwardTitle: Law and Social Science Dissertation Fellowship & Mentoring Program 2013-2018

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support the Law and Social Science Pre-Dissertation Fellowship and Mentoring Program administered through the Law and Society Association (LSA) and the American Bar Foundation (ABF) in conjunction with a faculty advisory and mentoring board. NSF funding will support a national search to identify and recruit eight academically talented graduate students who will complete two-year fellowships in Law and Social Science in residence at the ABF over the next five years. In their residence at ABF, fellows will have office space and facilities and will participate in all the activities in which ABF dissertation fellows participate. Fellows will receive living stipends to support two years of graduate study in a Ph.D. program in the social sciences. LSA will match each fellow with two individual mentors who are established scholars in the law and social science field. Additionally, LSA will provide collective mentoring in partnership with ABF through a series of workshops, colloquia, and conferences for fellows designed to nurture and sustain intellectual networks between fellows and established scholars in the field.

The Fellowships have two broad objectives: to enhance the capacity for rigorous, interdisciplinary, social scientific research on law and inequality, and to increase the diversity of scholars in the law and social science field, with special attention to increasing the number of researchers from underrepresented racial and ethnic minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Law and Social Science (LSS) Dissertation Fellowship & Mentoring program is a graduate student training program that provided mentoring, professional development, and interdisciplinary scholarly programming for young scholars in the field of LSS. This fellowship program took place from 2008-2018 and funded 18 doctoral students for two years each. The Fellows were supported jointly by the Law and Society Association (LSA) and the American Bar Foundation (ABF), and the Fellowships were held in-residence at the ABF.

The Fellowship program emphasized mentoring and professional development for the next generation of LSS scholars, with an emphasis on recruiting and supporting scholars from underrepresented groups. LSS is a very interdisciplinary field, but many graduate students doing LSS research are trained in departments that focus primarily on one discipline. The LSS Dissertation Fellowship program aimed to expose young scholars to the interdisciplinary nature of the field and provide opportunities for mentoring and professional development. To support this goal, Fellows were each provided with two mentors to guide their fellowship experience. Additionally, the Fellows had opportunities to participate in LSA workshops, ABF seminars, Chicago-area scholarly groups, and other professional development opportunities.

The doctoral Fellows supported by this award all finished their PhDs and secured employment in a related field. The Fellows completed dissertations on LSS topics such as higher education policy, police practices, internet governance, procedural protections for inmates, social group relations, and others. The majority of our past Fellows are now employed as professors; other current positions include Research Scientists, Fellowships, and Postdoctoral training. During and after their fellowships, our funded students published papers, secured grant funding, and gave presentations. The Fellows trained by this award and their continuing scholarly work will have an impact on the LSS field and society for many years to come.
